name: Batrachospermum

Identifying Characteristics: Branching filaments arranged loosely around a center, forming a somewhat spherical branching mass
May grow to be the size of a tennis-ball or larger
Pink, purple, blue-green, green, brown, or yellow in color
Under magnification, the tear-drop shaped cells, forming long, branched, threadlike filaments may be seen (like little glass beads strung on a thread)
The delicate strands feel slimy, gelatinous, to the touch.
Biology: Propagation through sexual reproduction; the male cells (antheridia) do not swim, meeting the female cells (carpogonium) simply by chance as they drift upon the current; after fertilization, spores are formed in clusters around the base of the carpogonium.
Has a wide environmental tolerance with respect to light, current velocity, pH and temperature
Habitat: Lakes, ponds, wetlands, pools in sphagnum bogs
Common in slow-flowing streams, especially shady sites

tags: branching algae that resemble higher plants
